Dear Ms. Koerber:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
5/16/2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Modified Implementation Sustainability, and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a written
corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules
are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15
days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved; this includes identifying
behaviorally specific action steps.
o Repeat violations must include an explanation of why the previous
corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
 Individuals directly responsible for implementing the corrective action step for
each licensing statute and rule, Contract item, DHHS policy or MISEP section
citation; e.g. workers, supervisors, program managers, director, etc.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
implemented and completed.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved; this
includes identifying specific action steps for continuous monitoring.
o MiSACWIS users with access to the Book of Business, InfoView Reports
and the Monthly Child Welfare Management Report should incorporate the
use of these tools as well as other data management reports released by
the Department for continuous monitoring.
 Signature of the responsible party and date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.
Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that
each employee and volunteer who has contact with
residents 4 or more hours per week for more than 2
consecutive weeks is free from communicable
tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable tuberculosis
shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current
verification.
Three of twelve personnel files reviewed did not have the Tuberculosis screening
completed as required. This involved three expired screenings.
R 400.4506 Fire drills and telephone.
(1) There shall be quarterly emergency fire drills for each
staff shift. Two of the drills shall include evacuations,
unless approved by the department, in writing, as clinically
contraindicated. Where a facility has a 24-hour staff shift,
the emergency drills shall be conducted at different times
of the day and night. Written records shall be maintained
for each drill indicating the date and time of the drill and,
where evacuation was a part of the drill, the approximate
evacuation time.
Three of twelve required fire drills were missing from the documentation provided.
This involved two first shift drills and one third shift drill missing.
2.) The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
 When documenting the fire drills all information should be included on one
sheet. This should include the time, date, if it was an evacuation and the
evacuation time.
 When documenting the room checks, staff should record the specific time the
check was completed.

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 Development of a specific electronic filing system for youth files.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The facility has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period which was in response to their Renewal
Inspection in 2021. During this Renewal Inspection, the facility was cited for having
seven of ten employee files without the required performance evaluation occurring.
The facility developed a CAP that involved a process of the Clinical Director reviewing
the schedule for employee evaluations every 2 months. The Clinical Director’s finding
will be provided to the Program Coordinator who will confirm the evaluations are
competed. During this inspection, 11 of 12 personnel files reviewed, required the
performance evaluation. All 11 files had the performance evaluation completed as
required.
Currently, the facility is in the process in increasing their bed capacity to 7. The facility
has reached out to the zoning department to start the process and they are waiting for
the zoning inspection to be scheduled. They were informed they need the zoning
approval before they can have the fire inspection. Once the zoning is approved, they
will schedule the fire inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment
A review of the Chief Administrator’s Assessment took place. This document outlines
the progress made on the CAP for the last inspection in 2021. The Clinical Director
left the facility, and the CAP was adjusted to include the Executive Director and Chief
Administrator reviewing for the evaluations. There was one violation, and the facility
is reported to have continued the oversite of personnel files. Once a month the
executive director meets with the manager responsible for evaluations to process
upcoming employee evaluations. During this inspection, all required evaluations were
completed as required. Also documented on this report is efforts to make changes to
the violations identified during this inspection. These issues will be outlined in the
required CAP.
Interviews
Interviews were completed with direct care staff, supervisors, and administrator. All
report the facility is a positive place for employment with a strong focus on meeting
the needs of the youth enrolled in the program. Staff report the facility is providing
appropriate training which helps provide care for the youth. Administration is open to
feedback and seeks ways of improving the service to youth. The four youth were
observed and but were non-verbal, so they were unable to be interviewed. Their
2

interactions with staff appeared very appropriate. Staff were very attentive to the
needs of the youth.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on their regular license.
